Acquire Lock Before Releasing Python GIL

data.author: Jacob Gunderson
data.message: Lock before releasing GIL

data.author: Christian Rauch
data.message:
Merge pull request #384 from Jgunde/patch-1

Release Python Global Interpreter Lock During Detection

data.author: Jacob Gunderson
data.message:
Release GIL during detection

Python's Global Interpreter Lock prevents other threads of a process from running. By releasing the GIL during the CPU intensive detection stage, other threads are allowed to run.

Merge pull request #360 from cottsay/cottsay/top-level-tests

Call enable_testing() in top-level project

data.author: Scott K Logan
data.message:
Call enable_testing() in top-level project

Per CMake documentation, this should be called in the top-level
CMakeLists.txt so that testing is enabled for the _project_, and not a
subdirectory thereof. This will allow tools like colcon to discover the
tests.

data.author: Jeffrey
data.message:
Fix the inconsistent image coordinate conventions.

The convention that (0,0) be the left top corner of
the first pixel is adopted in this commit.

In the previous versions, the coordinate convention
used for `quad_decimate = 1, refine_edges = false` is
already `left-top-corner = (0,0)`;
while for `quad_decimate > 1` or `refine_edges = true`,
the convention is vague since it seems mixed conventions
are used and some code even be wrong (see
https://github.com/AprilRobotics/apriltag/issues/345).

This fix ensures the same convention be used no matter
what values for `quad_decimate` and `refine_edges`.

data.author: Jeffrey
data.message:
Use bilinear interpolation in refine_edges()

A fix in refine_edges(): Use continuous coordinates
and bilinear interpolation (instead of discrete
coordinates) to fetch grayscale values from the input
image.

Using discrete coordinates and pixel values, as done
in the previous versions before this commit, might
incur errors caused by rounding effects, resulting
in instability. While in this commit, the bilinear
interpolation is employed, which doesn't change the
*average output* of refine_edges(), but just makes
the output more smooth and stable.

data.author: Christian Rauch
data.message:
Merge pull request #339 from berteauxjb/fix/workerpool

Fix spurious wake-ups and worker threads initialization in workerpool

data.author: Jean-Bernard Berteaux
data.message: workerpool: Properly wait for initialization of worker threads

data.author: Jean-Bernard Berteaux
data.message:
workerpool: Add predicate to condition variable startcond

Threads that wait on the condition variable startcond can be woken up
spuriously. This is not a problem if no tasks have been added, but as
soon as there is one, the condition in the while loop of worker_thread
will evaluate to false and the worker thread will run the task. If more
tasks are added, there is a chance that the zarray is reallocated and
that its pointer is changed. Since the woker thread gets a raw pointer
to the zarray, this pointer can become invalid and cause a segfault.

The solution is to add a predicate that is checked when the worker
thread is woken up on the condition variable startcond. The while loop
now has 2 conditions:
- start condition: if wp->start_tasks is true, tasks can be executed
- stop condition: if wp->taskspos == zarray_size(wp->tasks), there are
no more tasks to execute

I also shielded concurrent accesses to the pointer wp with the mutex.

data.author: Christian Rauch
data.message:
Merge pull request #332 from peci1/patch-1

apriltag_quad_thresh: Prevent conversion from NaN to int

data.author: Martin Pecka
data.message:
apriltag_quad_thresh: Prevent using decimate for scale smaller than 1

The rest of the codebase treats all values equal to 1 or smaller as disablers of the decimation. This function was the only one behaving differently. After this commit, the behavior will be consistent.

Especially, value 0.0 led to division by zero and then conversion of NaN, to int, which is undefined behavior.

Signed-off-by: Martin Pecka<peckama2@fel.cvut.cz>

data.author: Christian Rauch
data.message:
Merge pull request #308 from AustinSchuh/dedup_at_source

Stop adding duplicate points to the clusters.

data.author: Austin Schuh
data.message:
Fix perimeter threshold

April tags will only have straight sides.  With the deduplication
happening earlier, each pixel along that boundary will now only
have 2 neighbors (one above, one at 45 degrees).  We should adjust the
max blob length threshold accordingly.

Signed-off-by: Austin Schuh <austin.linux@gmail.com>

data.author: Austin Schuh
data.message:
Stop adding duplicate points to the clusters.

The segmentation system was adding duplicate points to the clusters list
before removing them later.

This has 2 problems.
  1) It is more expensive to remove them later than not to add them.
  2) When sorting, multiple slopes can have the same calculated slope
     value.  Depending on the initial order, the duplicates can end up
     being in non-adjacent slots in the cluster, and won't get
     de-duplicated later.

This takes my sample image on my test box from:
 0                             init        0.000000 ms        0.000000 ms
 1                         decimate        0.292000 ms        0.292000 ms
 2                       blur/sharp        0.000000 ms        0.292000 ms
 3                        threshold        0.617000 ms        0.909000 ms
 4                        unionfind        3.746000 ms        4.655000 ms
 5                    make clusters        9.461000 ms       14.116000 ms
 6            fit quads to clusters       16.310000 ms       30.426000 ms
 7                            quads        0.087000 ms       30.513000 ms
 8                decode+refinement        0.869000 ms       31.382000 ms
 9                        reconcile        0.001000 ms       31.383000 ms
10                     debug output        0.001000 ms       31.384000 ms
11                          cleanup        0.003000 ms       31.387000 ms

to

 0                             init        0.000000 ms        0.000000 ms
 1                         decimate        0.303000 ms        0.303000 ms
 2                       blur/sharp        0.001000 ms        0.304000 ms
 3                        threshold        0.640000 ms        0.944000 ms
 4                        unionfind        3.645000 ms        4.589000 ms
 5                    make clusters        8.593000 ms       13.182000 ms
 6            fit quads to clusters       13.935000 ms       27.117000 ms
 7                            quads        0.084000 ms       27.201000 ms
 8                decode+refinement        0.827000 ms       28.028000 ms
 9                        reconcile        0.002000 ms       28.030000 ms
10                     debug output        0.000000 ms       28.030000 ms
11                          cleanup        0.004000 ms       28.034000 ms

(across 10 runs, and picking one of the faster 10 runs for the original
and the slowest for the new)

Signed-off-by: Austin Schuh <austin.linux@gmail.com>

data.author: Christian Rauch
data.message:
Merge pull request #305 from AustinSchuh/mse_speedup

Speed up quad_segment_maxima by skipping unneeded lineparam calculation.

data.author: Austin Schuh
data.message:
Speed up quad_segment_maxima by skipping unneeded lineparam calculation.

In quad_segment_maxima, nothing uses params23 and params30, but these
are calculated anyways.  The compiler isn't smart enough to know that
there are no side effects, so it doesn't skip calculating them.

On my test box, this takes
            fit quads to clusters        8.896000 ms       23.968000 ms
to
            fit quads to clusters        8.429000 ms       23.490000 ms

which is measurable.

Signed-off-by: Austin Schuh <austin.linux@gmail.com>

data.author: Christian Rauch
data.message:
Merge pull request #280 from bouk/bouk/faster-cluster-merge

Speed up cluster merge by batch copying arrays

data.author: Bouke van der Bijl
data.message:
Speed up cluster merge by batch copying arrays

merge_clusters was using zarray_add_all which was copying over elements
one-by-one doing 2 memcpys and a potential array resize per element.
Here we replace it by a range copy that does a single resize and memcpy
for the operation which is a lot faster.

In my testing it reduces the total runtime for an image that's 2000x3000
by 20%.

data.author: Christian Rauch
data.message:
Merge pull request #271 from AustinSchuh/gradient_clusters_chunks

Split work up in gradient_clusters more finely

data.author: Austin Schuh
data.message:
Split work up in gradient_clusters more finely

In other chunks of work split into thread pools, the work is split up
more finely than the number of CPUs.  This makes it so that if a thread
gets behind (in a big.little architecture, this is expected, or in the
case of preemption), the threads that are ahead can pick up the extra
work.

gradient_clusters was missing this split.  This saved 5-10ms of
processing time on my Rock Pi 4b and reduced the outliers.

data.author: Wolfgang Merkt
data.message:
Fix for #167 for CMake versions <3.11

IMPORTED_GLOBAL is only available in CMake 3.11 and newer. Ubuntu 18.04
ships with CMake 3.10 and thus failed to configure projects using
AprilTag v3.15. This fix only activates the backwards-compatible ALIAS
target when using a new, supported CMake version.

data.author: Alexandre Tuleu
data.message:
Improves build system for edge cases. (#111)

* Uses PROJECT_SOURCE_DIR instead of CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR

When trying to build apriltag using cmake `ExternalProject_Add` or
`FetchContent`, the build will fail as the python and tag macro does
not work anymore.

In such a case `CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR` refers to the parent cmake project
that uses `ExternalProject_Add` and therefore the python wrapper nor
the tag family source are found.

Using `PROJECT_SOURCE_DIR` solves the issue as it refers in any
situation to the apriltag project source dir, which I believ was the
intended behavior.

* Makes python wrapper optionnal (old behavior conserved).

If an user does have python installed but numpy not installed, an
error will be shown.

The compiltaion of the wrapper should be optional (and maybe if set to
On should produce error). This patch just skip the build of the
wrapper if the user explicitely disable it. It defaults to the old behavior.
